levels.title: Engineering Manager
levels.scope: Single team (5-10 engineers), owns team execution and people management
keyDifferences: Manages ICs directly with regular 1:1s and career conversations
Owns sprint execution, delivery commitments, and team velocity
Partners with PM on team roadmap and backlog prioritization
First point of escalation for technical and interpersonal issues
Drives hiring for their team and owns onboarding experience
Responsible for team health, morale, and day-to-day culture
promotionBlockers: Cannot delegate — does everything themselves and becomes a bottleneck
No evidence of cross-team impact or influence beyond their own team
Team cannot function without them; no succession or knowledge sharing
Avoids difficult performance conversations or delays PIPs
Focuses only on execution with no strategic thinking about team direction
transitionSignals: Proactively solving cross-team problems without being asked
Coaching other EMs informally on people management challenges
VP or Director seeks their input on org-level decisions
Successfully navigated a team reorg or significant scope change
Built repeatable processes that other teams have adopted

levels.title: Senior Engineering Manager
levels.scope: 2-3 teams (12-25 engineers), owns cross-team coordination and technical strategy for a product area
keyDifferences: Manages EMs and/or tech leads in addition to some ICs
Owns cross-team coordination and dependency management within their area
Drives technical strategy and architecture decisions for their product area
Represents engineering in cross-functional leadership forums
Leads hiring strategy across multiple teams including pipeline building
promotionBlockers: Still operating as a hands-on EM rather than leading through other managers
Cannot articulate a coherent technical vision for their area
Struggles to manage competing priorities across their teams
Does not invest in developing their direct reports as leaders
Avoids organizational politics and fails to build cross-functional relationships
transitionSignals: Successfully led a multi-team initiative with significant org-wide impact
Developed an EM who was promoted into a leadership role
Proposed and executed a reorganization that improved team effectiveness
Built strong relationships with senior leaders outside engineering
Regularly consulted by peers on organizational design and team health

levels.title: Director of Engineering
levels.scope: 4-8 teams (30-60 engineers), owns engineering strategy for a business domain and manages a team of managers
keyDifferences: Manages managers exclusively; no direct IC reports
Owns engineering strategy and roadmap for an entire business domain
Drives headcount planning, budget allocation, and resource tradeoffs
Accountable for org health metrics: attrition, engagement, diversity
Partners with VP and C-suite on company-level technical decisions
Shapes engineering culture through policy, rituals, and norms
promotionBlockers: Cannot translate business strategy into engineering priorities
Micromanages their managers instead of coaching and empowering them
Lacks credibility with executive leadership or board-level stakeholders
Fails to build a leadership pipeline — always hiring externally for manager roles
Reactive to organizational issues rather than proactively shaping the org
transitionSignals: Influenced company-level strategy beyond their own domain
Successfully scaled the org through a period of rapid growth or contraction
Built a self-sustaining leadership team that operates effectively in their absence
Drove a major technical or organizational transformation end-to-end
Recognized as a thought leader internally and externally in engineering leadership

levels.title: Senior Director of Engineering
levels.scope: 8-15 teams (60-150 engineers), manages multiple Directors and owns entire product verticals or engineering pillars
keyDifferences: Manages Directors; responsible for leadership development across management layers
Owns engineering strategy for multiple business domains or an entire product vertical
Drives org-wide technical initiatives: platform migrations, architecture standards, build-vs-buy at scale
Represents engineering at company strategy level alongside VP and C-suite
Owns budget and headcount planning across multiple Director orgs
Leads through crisis at organizational scale — layoffs, acquisitions, major incidents
promotionBlockers: Cannot operate at company strategy altitude — stays in domain-level thinking
Does not develop Directors into senior leaders; leadership pipeline is thin
Struggles to build executive-level relationships outside engineering
Cannot drive org-wide change without VP air cover
Reactive to cross-domain dependencies rather than proactively aligning engineering pillars
transitionSignals: Trusted to represent the VP in executive forums and make binding decisions
Multiple Directors in their org are promotion-ready
Drove an org-wide transformation (platform, process, culture) end-to-end
Built coalitions across executive team for engineering-led initiatives
Engineering brand and culture under their purview attracts external leadership talent

levels.title: VP of Engineering
levels.scope: Entire engineering organization (60-300+ engineers), owns engineering as a function and sits on the leadership team
keyDifferences: Owns the engineering function end-to-end: strategy, execution, people, culture
Reports to CTO or CEO; accountable to board for engineering outcomes
Drives multi-year technical strategy aligned with business objectives
Owns the engineering budget and makes final headcount allocation decisions
Represents engineering externally: recruiting brand, conference talks, partnerships
Navigates company politics and builds coalitions across the executive team
promotionBlockers: Cannot operate at the executive level — gets pulled into tactical details
Fails to build trust with CEO, CFO, or board members
Engineering is seen as a cost center rather than a strategic asset under their leadership
Does not develop Directors who can own domains independently
Lacks a compelling multi-year vision for the engineering organization
transitionSignals: Engineering is recognized as a competitive advantage by the board
Multiple Directors in the org are ready-now candidates for VP roles elsewhere
Successfully navigated a major crisis (acquisition, reorg, layoff) with org trust intact
Drove a company-level initiative that required cross-functional executive alignment
Built an engineering culture that attracts top talent and has industry recognition
